description: DMI/SMBIOS table decoder - displays hardware information from BIOS. Dmidecode reads the System Management BIOS (SMBIOS) or Desktop Management Interface (DMI) data from the BIOS and presents it in human-readable format. This includes detailed information about system hardware components such as system manufacturer, model, serial number, BIOS version, processor sockets, memory modules, chassis type, and more. Essential for HPC environments to inventory hardware, verify system configurations, check memory topology, and identify hardware for warranty and support purposes.

installation.notes: Part of the dmidecode package, typically available in default repositories. Requires root privileges to access SMBIOS/DMI tables via /dev/mem or /sys/firmware/dmi/tables.

global_options.description: Only display entries of the specified type. Type can be a keyword (bios, system, baseboard, chassis, processor, memory, cache, connector, slot) or a numeric DMI type (0-42).
Only display the value of the specified DMI string. String must be a keyword like system-manufacturer, system-product-name, bios-version, etc.
Be less verbose. Unknown, inactive, and OEM-specific entries are not displayed. Only meaningful information is shown.
Do not decode the entries, dump their contents as hexadecimal instead. Useful for debugging or when exact binary data is needed.
Dump the DMI data to a binary file for later processing or debugging.
Read the DMI data from a binary dump file instead of from memory. Useful for offline analysis.
Do not attempt to read DMI data from sysfs files. Only read from /dev/mem.
Only display the value of the specified OEM string number.
Read memory from device FILE (default: /dev/mem). Useful when DMI data is at a non-standard location.
Only display the entry whose handle matches HANDLE. Handles are 16-bit unique identifiers for each DMI structure.

output_formats.default: Human-readable text format with DMI type headers and key-value pairs for each structure.
output_formats.string: Single line output containing only the requested string value (-s option).
output_formats.hexdump: Hexadecimal dump of raw DMI data structures (-u option).
output_formats.binary: Raw binary dump of DMI tables for offline processing (--dump-bin option).

exit_codes.meaning: Error - general failure such as permission denied or DMI data not found

error_messages.meaning: The command was run without root privileges
error_messages.resolution: Run dmidecode with sudo or as root: sudo dmidecode

error_messages.meaning: The system has an older SMBIOS version that may not contain all expected information
error_messages.resolution: This is informational. Some features may be limited on older systems.

error_messages.message: No SMBIOS nor DMI entry point found, sorry.
error_messages.meaning: DMI/SMBIOS data could not be found in memory or sysfs
error_messages.resolution: Verify the system has SMBIOS support. On virtual machines, ensure DMI passthrough is enabled. Check if /sys/firmware/dmi/tables exists.

error_messages.meaning: The DMI table address points to inaccessible memory
error_messages.resolution: Try running with --no-sysfs option, or check kernel configuration for DMI support.

error_messages.message: Invalid entry length (0). DMI table is broken, stop decoding.
error_messages.meaning: Corrupted or malformed DMI table data
error_messages.resolution: This may indicate BIOS issues. Try updating the system BIOS/UEFI firmware.

Use a valid keyword. Common keywords: bios-vendor, bios-version, bios-release-date, system-manufacturer, system-product-name, system-serial-number, baseboard-manufacturer, baseboard-product-name, chassis-type.

interoperability.notes: dmidecode reads SMBIOS/DMI tables from /sys/firmware/dmi/tables (preferred) or directly from /dev/mem. The information comes from the system BIOS and may not reflect actual hardware state (e.g., if BIOS is not updated after hardware changes). For real-time hardware information, combine with lshw, lspci, and lscpu. The biosdecode and vpddecode utilities from the same package can extract additional BIOS data.

permissions.read_operations: Requires root privileges to access /dev/mem or /sys/firmware/dmi/tables. Reading from a dump file does not require root.
permissions.write_operations: dmidecode is read-only and does not modify any system state.
permissions.notes: On systems with Secure Boot or restricted /dev/mem access, dmidecode may need kernel module loading or specific kernel parameters. Some containers may not have access to DMI tables.

limitations: Information accuracy depends on BIOS vendor implementation - some fields may be missing or incorrect
Virtual machines may show hypervisor-defined values rather than physical hardware details
Cannot detect hardware changes that occurred after BIOS initialization without a reboot
Memory modules replaced at runtime will not be reflected until next boot
Container environments typically do not have access to DMI tables
Some newer hardware features may not be decoded until dmidecode is updated
OEM-specific fields may not be decoded or may show as raw data

reads_from.description: Reads hardware inventory information from SMBIOS/DMI tables stored by the system BIOS. This includes manufacturer details, serial numbers, memory topology, processor specifications, and chassis information.

consistent_with.shared_state: System manufacturer, model, serial number, and memory configuration should match between both tools
Processor socket count, core count, and CPU model should be consistent with dmidecode processor output
Total system memory reported should match the sum of installed DIMMs from dmidecode -t memory
PCIe slot designations and bus addresses from dmidecode -t slot should correspond to lspci device locations
